| Name                                                                           | flint stone                                 |

A **flint stone** is a type of [gem](/wiki/Gem "Gem") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. Flint stones are [ammunition](/wiki/Ammunition "Ammunition") made for [firing](/wiki/Firing "Firing") with [slings](/wiki/Sling "Sling"). The flint stone appears as a **[gray stone](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone")** when unidentified, and is the only gray stone to be a non-[magical item](/wiki/Magical_item "Magical item").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

In addition to random generation, general [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop") and jewelers can sell flint stones.

[Cavepeople](/wiki/Cavepeople "Cavepeople") start with a stack of flint stones to use as ammo for their sling.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Two of the possible maps for [Mines' End](/wiki/Mines%27_End "Mines' End") place a flint stone at level creation: the Mimic of the Mines map has a flint stone in one of the many gem piles, and the Catacombs map has a flint stone as the other gray stone present on the level.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit 51a5550](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/51a5550a5186310b0ea08c8b0a17ee1085bef062), [hobbits](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit") generated with a sling will also receive a stack of flint stones.

## Description

Flint stones do 1d6 damage against small and large enemies when slung, compared to 1d3 for other gems and stones.

There is code for [a specific message](/wiki/YAFM "YAFM") that is printed if a character [eats](/wiki/Eat "Eat") a non-cursed flint stone, and doing so would exercise [constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-vitamin-3) This is not yet possible in *NetHack*.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit b1f8c3d5](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/b1f8c3d5c19e535901523fc86a1b2fb381b87c3f), flint stones can be wished for safely in stacks of up to 20. Per [commit 733fc849](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/733fc849348287bbdff364cef04257b80a5b211f), flint is also less likely to mulch when thrown or fired.

## Strategy

While they are the least interesting of the gray stones by far, flint stones are the safest to pick up and carry. They are also trivial to identify informally: [rubbing](/wiki/Rubbing "Rubbing") can easily detect [touchstones](/wiki/Touchstone "Touchstone"), and their 1 [zm](/wiki/Zm "Zm") base cost makes [price identification](/wiki/Price_identification "Price identification") to distinguish them from [luckstones](/wiki/Luckstone "Luckstone") straightforward; [loadstones](/wiki/Loadstone "Loadstone") are also 1 zm, but can easily be kick-tested or pet-tested even outside of [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop").

If a [hobbit](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit") or other hostile monster slings a gray stone at you, it is most likely flint.

## History

The flint stone first appears in [NetHack 3.2.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.0 "NetHack 3.2.0"), and effectively serves as a replacement for the [sling bullet](/wiki/Sling_bullet "Sling bullet") from previous versions.

## Messages

- Yabba-dabba delicious!

  A character ate a non-cursed flint stone - this requires the polymorph form of a [lithivore](/wiki/Lithivore "Lithivore") monster, which currently does not exist in *NetHack* - the comment on the message indicates that this is a reference to the TV series *[The Flintstones](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Flintstones "wikipedia:The Flintstones")* and the *Flintstones* brand of children's vitamin tablets.[\[3\]](#cite_note-vitamin-3)

## Variants

Some variants make flint stones much more commonplace.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [upgrading](/wiki/Upgrading "Upgrading") a flint stone produces either a luckstone or a [healthstone](/wiki/Healthstone "Healthstone"), and upgrading a loadstone produces a flint stone.

A magical gray stone (i.e. not a flint stone or [whetstone](/wiki/Whetstone "Whetstone")) that is [dipped](/wiki/Dipped "Dipped") in a [potion of amnesia](/wiki/Potion_of_amnesia "Potion of amnesia"), or else submerged in [Lethe water](/wiki/Lethe_water "Lethe water"), becomes a flint stone.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), the "intact" map for the sixth floor of the [Ruins of Moria](/wiki/Ruins_of_Moria "Ruins of Moria") generates a flint stone in the "Twenty-First Hall" opposite the warehouse at level creation.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), all non-[vampire](/wiki/Vampire_\(starting_race_in_dNetHack\) "Vampire (starting race in dNetHack)") [Binders](/wiki/Binder "Binder") start with a flint stone.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), the flint stone's [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight") is reduced to 2 aum, and flint stones are more likely to generate in stacks.

[Hobbits](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit") are always generated with a stack of flint stones to use as sling ammo.

xNetHack displays the weight of items in the inventory, making flint stones trivial to identify.

Rubbing or applying an existing flint stone against a handful of rocks has a chance of producing one or more new flint stones. This makes for an almost endless supply of projectiles.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), hobbits and [hobbit pickpockets](/wiki/Hobbit_pickpocket "Hobbit pickpocket") have a 2⁄3 chance of generating with flint stones as their sling ammo. [Player monster](/wiki/Player_monster_\(EvilHack\) "Player monster (EvilHack)") cavepeople will always generate with flint stones to use as sling ammo.

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details, [lithivores](/wiki/Lithivore "Lithivore") can eat flint stones and other mineral objects - a character in the form of a lithivore will produce the unused message above when eating a flint stone.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), flint weighs 2 aum as in xNetHack.

Magical gray stones dipped in a potion of amnesia become flint stones, as in SLASH'EM. Hobbits and hobbit pickpockets have the same odds of generating with flint stones as in EvilHack.

## Encyclopedia entry

An emerald is as green as grass;  
A ruby red as blood;  
A sapphire shines as blue as heaven;  
A flint lies in the mud.  
  
A diamond is a brilliant stone,  
To catch the world's desire;  
An opal holds a fiery spark;  
But a flint holds fire.

\[ Precious Stones, by Christina Giorgina Rossetti ]

2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 83](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/eat.c#L83): *`is_edible` function does not list rocks*
3. ↑ [3.0](#cite_ref-vitamin_3-0) [3.1](#cite_ref-vitamin_3-1) [src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2141](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/eat.c#L2141)
